questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Philippians 2:1-18 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between self-centeredness and Christ's humility in verses 5-8.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'in Christ Jesus' (v.5, 6, 7, 8) emphasizes unity in Christ
Observe the progression from 'same mind' (v.1) to Christ's emptying (v.5-8) and the result (v.9-11)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being called to unity, WHAT they are to do, WHERE this happens (the church in Philippi), and WHY (to reflect Christ's humility).
tips: Include the call for mutual love and unity (v.1-4)
Note the example of Christ emptying Himself (v.5-8)
Describe the result: every knee bowing and every tongue confessing (v.9-11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Christ's emptying (v.5-8), the call for humility (v.3-4), or the universal response (v.9-11)?
tips: The phrase 'emptying Himself' (v.6) shows Christ's radical humility - a concept that challenges self-centeredness
The contrast in v.5-8: 'who was in the form of God' vs. 'emptied Himself' is profound
The promise in v.10-11: 'every knee will bow' is a powerful declaration of Christ's universal authority

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Philippi through this passage?
tips: Paul is calling the Philippians to embrace the same mind as Christ - humility and selflessness
This passage shows that true unity and Christian identity come from Christ's example of humility
The theological significance is that Christ's humility leads to exaltation and universal submission

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of Christ 'emptying' Himself? The call for selflessness? The universal response of every knee bowing?
tips: 'Emptying' (Greek: kenosis) means Christ voluntarily relinquishing His divine equality without ceasing to be God
The call for humility is challenging in a culture that values status and success
The universal response (v.9-11) might seem too absolute, but it points to Christ's authority over all creation

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice the mind of Christ in your relationships this week?
tips: Choose one person to serve without expecting anything in return (like Christ did)
Reflect on a time you were proud and ask how you can humble yourself
Share the good news of Christ's humility with someone who is self-centered

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He provides. Ask for Abraham-like faith to trust and obey even when it's costly.
tips: Thank God for the example of Christ's humility
Pray for the courage to be humble and to serve others
Ask God to strengthen your trust in His provision

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Philippians 3:1-16 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of Paul's surrender and the repeated phrase 'knowing Christ'.
tips: Notice the phrase 'I count everything as loss because of the surpassing worth of knowing Christ Jesus' (v.8) appears multiple times in the passage
Pay attention to the contrast between Paul's past (v.4-6) and his present focus (v.8-11)
The phrase 'pressing on toward the goal' (v.14) shows active pursuit, not passive waiting

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO Paul is talking about, WHAT he has counted as loss, WHERE this is happening (the church in Philippi), and WHY he emphasizes knowing Christ above all.
tips: Include Paul's past identity: circumcised on the eighth day, Pharisee, persecutor of the church
Note that Paul counts everything as loss for the sake of knowing Christ
The goal is to be found in Christ and to attain resurrection to life

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: 'I count everything as loss' (v.7), 'pressing on toward the goal' (v.14), or 'our citizenship is in heaven' (v.20)?
tips: 'I count everything as loss' shows Paul's radical surrender to Christ, even his past achievements as worthless
'Pressing on toward the goal' emphasizes active pursuit of Christ, not passive waiting
'Our citizenship is in heaven' shifts focus from earthly life to eternal identity

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Paul trying to communicate to the church in Philippi through this passage?
tips: Paul is emphasizing that the surpassing worth of knowing Christ is more valuable than any human status or achievement
This passage shows that true righteousness comes through faith in Christ, not the law
The goal of the Christian life is to be found in Christ and to be transformed by His resurrection power

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The phrase 'counting everything as loss', the contrast between law and faith, or the concept of 'pressing on'?
tips: 'Counting everything as loss' (v.7) is a radical perspective that challenges the value we place on human accomplishments and status
The contrast between 'righteousness of his own that comes from the law' and 'righteousness from God that depends on faith' (v.9) requires understanding that the law cannot provide righteousness
'Pressing on toward the goal' (v.14) is an active, continuous pursuit that may be difficult in a world that encourages passivity or immediate results

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you 'press on toward the goal' for Christ this week, given that your citizenship is in heaven?
tips: Identify one area where you are holding back from full obedience and consider what you can surrender to God
Practice daily steps that align with the goal of knowing Christ, such as prayer, studying the Bible, or sharing your faith
Remember that your true citizenship is in heaven, so focus on eternal things rather than temporary ones

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the surpassing worth of knowing Christ. Ask for the courage to count everything as loss and to press on toward the goal.
tips: Thank God for Christ as the only hope and the source of righteousness
Ask for the strength to let go of what is of earth and focus on the heavenly citizenship
Pray for the ability to be like Christ in suffering and death, and to be transformed by His resurrection power
